bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, September 25, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Kellogg for the acknowledgement included in the journal article on the Cornwell painting. However, he suggests a few changes to the acknowledgement.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, September 25, 1941
div1.opener:
September 26, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I am returning the two pages of proof, which are as I understand
it, to go with the reproduction of the yellow fever painting in the November 1
issue of the Journal of the A.M.A. I think it was mighty generous of you to
print such a nice and comprehensive acknowledgement. It is also a diplomatic
thing to do, and I hope that the Cubans won't backfire by suggesting that they
approve some other editorial idea than the one finally portrayed and that they
wash their hands of the present painting. The Mayo Clinic is of course sensi-
tive about the way its name is used in advertising matters but I see absolutely
no objection and indeed think it most kind of you to mention me so generously.
I asked the head of our editorial department and three or four of my close
friends if they thought anyone could criticize me or the Clinic for allowing my
name to be so used and they all said, “Absolutely not.” I do believe that you
exaggerated the value of my services to you in relation to the services of your
other official advisors, particularly Generals Kean and Truby, but of course
that matter is out of my hands.

Permit me to make two or three changes which I think are important.
First of all, in the list of acknowledgements, I believe it would be very dip-
lomatic to include Mrs. Estela Agramonte del Rodriguez Leon, Dr. Agramonte's
daughter. It is true that her comments and criticisms on the original and sub-
sequent versions were sent to you largely through me but I believe even before
the last letter that you just had from her that you had already had at least
one letter from her, and now, especially since her letter of September 11 to
you, I think it would be gracious to include her name. Perhaps her name could
be inserted as I have done on the proof, in the list of the Havana people.
However, if you think the expression “all of whom were personally consulted”
does not apply to her, I suggest that you include her in the next paragraph
after the names of the Mrs. Reed, and I would suggest that you identify her
as the daughter of Dr. Agramonte.

I am delighted to hear her comments about the final painting and in order
that you may send her one of the original engraver's proofs I am returning to you
for her one of the two you sent me. I think she will be most happy to have it
and I believe you will feel better about having sent her one. Later, you can send
me another of the large framed reproductions and I would appreciate it greatly
if Mr. Cornwell will autograph it. You can then send Miss Agramonte a few other
reproductions as she requests.

In the second paragraph of the printed key, the name Olson is spelled
with two “s's”. Please delete one “s”. No. 14 represents eleven additional
volunteers. Only ten are mentioned, the name Hildebrand having been left out.
Please insert this as marked.

One more point. Let me comment on the spelling of the names Olson
and Weatherwalks. The first is variously spelled Olson and Olsen. It is spelled
Olson on page 23 of the official Senate Document 822. It is also so spelled
in the following Congressional Bills: HR 13060 (1928), HR 11686 (1928) and
S 3364 (1928); it is also spelled Olson on page 10 of the Hearing before the
committee on military affairs of the House of Representatives April 11, 1928.
I assume, therefore, that that is the correct way to spell it despite the fact
that it is spelled Olsen on pages 28 and 104 of the Senate Document and also in
a letter dated April 16, 192 written by Colonel Kean and sent to Honorable John
Morin of the Committee on Military Affairs.

The other name is variously spelled Weatherwalk and Weatherwalks. It
is spelled Weatherwalks in Colonel Kean's letter just mentioned, also on page 23
of the official Senate Document 822, also in the three Congressional bills mentioned
above, but it is spelled Weatherwalk without the final “s” on pages 29 and 104 of
the Senate Document. By virtue of preponderance I suspect that the spellings
Olson and Weatherwalks are correct. It would be nice to have these names correct
in the Journal of the A.M.A. and elsewhere. I spelled them Olson and Weatherwalks
in the Hygeia article. Do you have time to check on this by writing to the War
Department? I believe the Chief of the Pension Bureau who sends out the Congressional
monthly awards to these men or their widows could give you the official spelling.
If you find it, will you please send me the correct spelling?

I am sending a carbon copy of this last page to Generals Kean and Truby
but I don't know whether they know which is correct or whether they could get me
the correct spelling in time to send it to you.

I was much interested in your conversations with Drs. Rankin and McCormack.
I was amused at Dr. Rankin's criticism about the helmets. I suppose criticism of
one sort or another will be popping up from time to time from various sources and it
will be interesting to see how many are justified and how many are not. It is
curious that Generals Kean and Truby did not criticize the sun helmets on the three
officers. Apparently you are finding almost as many conflicting stories about the
McDowell episode as you did about the yellow fever story but if you are as vigorous
in tracking down the truth as you were in the yellow fever story I am sure you will
have very few valid or serious criticisms of your vital work.

It is extremely generous of you to be willing to send me so many reprints.
I will await them with pleasant anticipation and assume that when you write Dr. Bauer
after hearing about the price of the whole 25,000 you will tell him that your order
includes mine and that he can ignore the letter that I sent him, a copy of which I
sent you. It might be just as convenient for him and much more convenient for you
and me if you would ask Dr. Bauer to ship me the 5,000 reprints directly rather than
having them shipped to you and then having you ship them here.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
